segments.text: One, two, three, four, one, two, three, four, one, two, three.
Testing, testing.
One, two, three, four, one, two, three.
One, two, three, four, one, two, three.
This is Tuesday, September the 5th in the Blocker Building and have the honor and pleasure of chatting with Dr. Janet McCann, Professor of English,
about her years here at Texas A&M.
To introduce yourself to someone who might read this transcription or hear the tape many years in the future, describe, if you will, your background.
Where'd you grow up?
What did parents do?
Where'd you go to high school and then college?
Experience before coming to A&M.
Okay.
I grew up in Newark, Delaware.
My mother was a language teacher and my father was a chemist.
I went to the University of Delaware at first and then I got thrown out of the University of Delaware for producing an illegal newspaper.
After that I went to Otterbein College and I graduated from there in 1963.
And then I went on to the University of Pittsburgh for my graduate degree.
I got the master's degree in 1964 and then
I was married in 65.
I had, though by that time, completed my coursework.
And so I finished up my doctoral degree at the University of Pittsburgh to receive it in 1974, ten years later.
But I came out here in 1968.
How did you and A&M become connected?
My husband took a job here in 1968, and that's when the job market slammed shut.
Before that, there were lots of jobs.
And in fact, with my master's degree in 64, I was offered a whole bunch of jobs.
But then all of a sudden, everything closed down.
And Hugh looked for a job.
all over, and finally found a job at Texas A&M, so he came out here to start teaching in the fall of 1964.
At that time we had one daughter, Stephanie, and I was pregnant with the second child.
Did you begin teaching that year here?
Yes, I did, but not at first.
I came out in the fall.
Lee Martin was then chair of the English department.
There was a professor who apparently had been behaving reprehensibly, and this person was booted out without ceremony.
And then Lee Martin hired me to take his place in the middle of the second semester in 1969, the spring of 1969, mid-semester I was hired.
So I took over classes, one Shakespeare class and two argumentation classes, and I was hired as an instructor then.
This is the only time I will ask you about salary.
What was the beginning salary in 1969?
The beginning salary was $8,000 a year.
However, we didn't get raises and I got that $8,000 a year for many years after that.
So there really wasn't a search process or a search committee or anything?
No, there certainly wasn't.
In fact,
I had sent in when I came out here and looked around.
Actually, I kind of suffered from culture shock because we'd just come from the University of Chicago.
And this place was very different from the rest of the world then.
For one thing, in the rest of the world, not everybody had pickups with gun racks in them.
This was something that struck my eye when I got off the bus because I came out on a bus.
For another, they then had in the Eagle, which was then the Bryan Eagle, they had a weekend, every weekend, they had a violent death toll.
which included stabbings and shootings and drownings as well as car crashes.
So I came here, and I thought I was on Mars.
I didn't like the activities for women because we were kind of supposed to be faculty wives, and this is not what I thought I trained for.
And so I was bored, and I sent a resume.
I was my newly minted master's on it, to the head of the English department.
Of course, I didn't get any response.
And I was complaining to Manuel Davenport at a rather well-oiled party about how crummy things were and how I wanted something to do.
And he said, go in and introduce yourself to the department chair.
And so I did this.
I was very uneasy about this kind of thing, but I went in, I said, hello, I'm Janet McCann, I'd like a job.
He said, well, I'll see what I can do for you next year.
And this was?
This was in the beginning of the spring.
And who was the department?
Lee Martin.
This was Lee, your company.
And he said, see what he could do for me in the fall.
He said he might have a class or two that nobody wanted.
Well, about a month later, he called me up and said, can you start teaching Monday?
So that was my beginning.
And this was to replace the faculty member?
Who had been given the royal toe, yes.
Would it be appropriate on this to discuss his alleged shortcomings?
Probably not.
They were fairly spectacular.
Okay, so I was hired to fill in for someone who had been fired, and I was not told any of the background of the situation.
And this was about what point in the semester?
This was in the middle of the semester.
So I had a bunch of students.
I got a grade book with a bunch of grades, and these students seemed extremely disorderly and rude.

And I had not got the impression that Aggies were like that, but due to apparently the strained relationships with the previous instructor, about which I was told nothing, I had a bunch of loony students all semester.
They said and did strange things in class.
They showed up when they felt like it and left when they felt like it.
I was going not, I was going to not teach here anymore.
I was going to look for something somewhere else.
But somebody confided in me that the previous instructor had set up bad relationships with the students and therefore I should give it another chance and take another semester if offered, so I did.
And of course they were completely different the second time.
All right, now those first classes you taught were what level courses?
I had a Shakespeare course, which was interesting, upper-level Shakespeare course.
Well, it's not upper-level, really.
Back then, there were very few courses.
And this is one thing that makes it very different from now.
There was no real hierarchy within the department.
That is, everybody taught the same thing.
There was not a lot of fighting for classes.
There were very few graduate classes, and they were, the graduate program was new.
The graduate classes were taught by the same people every time, so there was no fighting for those.
And otherwise, everybody taught the same survey classes, world lit, American lit, British lit.
There was Shakespeare.
I think there was, there was Chaucer.
I didn't ever teach that.
There were, there were classes in argumentation and freshman composition.
But we all took our turn teaching them, and I believe it was the head's position that everybody should have a class of freshman English a year, so we all did.
The department was located?
The department was in the academic building.
Describe it physically, about how many people and who were the senior folks?
Okay, the senior, there was John Paul Abbott and Carol Laverty.
There was Harrison Hearth.
There were Sid Cox and, oh gosh, scheduling fellow, Curtis Shoddy, who's still around.
Frank Pierce was there.
And I'm trying to think of others.
There was somebody named John Gwynne.
It was E.E.
Stokes.
There was a woman, one woman named Muriel Seville, and she was only there briefly, and she was the only woman who was a regular faculty member.
So one full-time female?
One full-time female if you don't count students.
There were a couple of students who were teaching, a couple of women students who were teaching full-time, but they were students.
And the normal workload then for a full-time faculty member in English was how many sections per semester?
That's hard to answer because I always had nine hours.
But one of the classes was always large, and they would count that as two classes.
So it was a theoretical 12-hour load, and some people did have 12-hour loads.
If you taught speech, for instance, you always had a 12-hour load.
But since they would count a class of 100, which I frequently had, as two classes, I always had a nine-hour load.
Now, the introductory survey courses had about how many students, the freshman English courses?
Oh, the freshman English courses.
They had, as now, a limit of 25, but they were often smaller.
Often you'd have 17 or 18 students in there.
Now, of course, they're always jammed.
As you were being introduced into the department, describe how the department received you.
How did they accept you or not accept you?
They didn't quite know what to do with me.
I was an instructor with a master's degree.
PhDs were not required for tenure track work then.
And in fact, some of the people, Steve Jernigan was there too.
And Steve and Sid and several others, Frank for that matter, did not have PhDs.
So that wasn't a problem.
I was the youngest person in the department.
That was kind of a problem.
I kind of fell between the graduate, in their minds, I kind of fell between the graduate students and the professors.
The graduate students were a very motley bunch then.
I was not, I think I was just kind of accepted by the younger people in the faculty who were still considerably older than I.
and overlooked entirely by the older people.
Some of them, Carol Laverty, for instance, persisted in thinking I was a graduate student.
And then the other people in the building didn't consider me, that is, people outside the English department.
I was constantly challenged on my right to use the elevator.
People would say, what department are you in?
And sometimes I got a little bit irritated with this.
And the graduate program was a master's degree only at that time?
No, it wasn't.
It was a PhD program.
The PhD was already authorized.
Yes, and I think that they graduated the first one about the year before I came or the year I came.
In terms of scholarship and reputation, who were the people best known in the department?
Well, no one had published anything.
I mean, Frank Pierce wrote mystery stories.
He was one of the best published.
Hearth...
And two of the others, I think Laverty and somebody else, had written a textbook that was used in the basic literature class, the 203.
And Lee Martin had written a textbook called The 500 Word Theme, which Harry Kreuter then revised.
And that was about it.
Scholarship wasn't the done thing.
Did you find anyone that you could turn to for advice in the department?
Who became a friend?
Stanley Archer.
Describe him.
Stanley Archer was always very reserved but extremely helpful.
And I always, in fact, until he died, I always went to Stanley Archer when I had some kind of naughty question.
Can you give an example of any of his advice, his counsel?

Well, several times that I had felt that I had been not treated right by the department or the university, and I went to Stanley Archer before doing anything about it, and Stanley Archer agreed that I had been
not treated right, and he looked over letters that I wrote concerning this that went to various people and made suggestions on the letters that were very useful.
Now, describe the
the students in your first years here?
Okay.
Leaving aside the bunch of loons I had the first semester, they were for the most part male.
In fact, in my first class, these are the ones I took over.
I had only two women in the three classes.
For the next four or five years, I had by far, I would say, oh, maybe three to one at least, men versus women.
They were all, for the most part, they were all white.
They were all, the uniforms were by far a greater presence.
You looked out in the class and you saw mostly uniforms.
They were very, they called me ma'am.
They were very obedient, again, leaving out this first lot.
However, they had no intellectual, many of them had no intellectual curiosity, and English was something they had to get through on their way to something else.

Sometimes they would develop, I always liked teaching Shakespeare, although I have no training in it because they had a tendency to bond with Shakespeare and to actually take an interest in what they were doing.
But as far as learning methods and materials of research, they were not into this.

the uh activities with those first students can you share any anecdotes of what it was like with their excuses or their uh did any of them ever try to put one over on you oh many times sure some of those okay one i had a this was a member of the corps of cadets and he was
He was missing for about two-thirds of the semester.

And then he reappeared with this letter assigned Dr. Anderson, urologist, with a complicated and detailed description of what was supposedly wrong with this young man's urinary system that had caused him to miss my class.
And it was supposedly signed by his father, too, and by Dr. Anderson.
And I read the thing, and it sounded a little funny.
I didn't think the doctor would be quite so free with the tales.
In fact, it sounded a little bit like it had been even taken from somewhere.
So I didn't, he was supposed to come around Monday.
I was supposed to, I went to a party on Friday evening, and there was Dr. Anderson.
So I asked him about this letter, and he said that the student had been to his office for some sort of minor problem at the beginning of the semester, but he had never written any letter for him.
This guy pinched the stationery.
And so he showed up on Monday, and I said, Mr. Smith, that's a pseudonym, would you like to hear what Dr. Anderson said about your letter?
And he said, no ma'am, I don't think I would, and I never saw him again.
My favorite is a youngster who told me the first day of the semester that his grandfather was very ill.
I expressed my concern, my sadness.
I hope it's not serious.
Oh, very serious.
Oh, gee, gee.
He said, in fact, he may not survive this semester.
I said, well, I'll work with you and we'll do the best we can.
As he walked out the door, he turned over his shoulder and he said, in fact, it's almost certain he's going to die the first day of deer season.
And he grinned as he walked away.
What about classroom behavior patterns?
How did Aggies behave in class in those early years?
Politely for the most part.
They tended to calculate what they needed to do to get through the course and do that much, and they were always polite.
Back then there was such a thing as a gentleman C that many of them were quite content to receive.
I never had any trouble with students in those first years at all, except for, again, leaving aside this first lot.
And a large core percentage in those years?
Yes.
And in general, were these country boys or city?
They were country boys for the most part.
And very few liberal arts majors.
Yes, few liberal arts majors.
And those who were, I tended not to get because I tended to teach basic classes.
On the other hand, there weren't that many specialized classes.
For instance, I am in creative writing, and that's what I do now.
I coordinate the creative writing classes.
There was no creative writing.
Then after years and years, Frank Pierce, I think, started creative writing, and Dick Costa taught creative writing.
And there was one class a year.
And you were lucky to get your 10 students that you needed to have that class make.
Now, of course, we have
We can't offer enough.
We, especially our 200-level courses, we always get.
We're offering four sections this time, and I had dozens and dozens of requests to be forced in, but you can't.
It's 25 students to teach creative writing.
That's enough students.
You can't do any more than that.
Teach them.
Describe registration in that era, in those early years.
As I recall, there were long tables.
There was a room somewhere, maybe in Heaton.
I don't remember where it was.
All right.
Now, Cebisa and G. Raleigh, or had we already moved out of that where faculty used to go on registration day, and the students went through there?
I don't remember where they were.
I just remember sitting at these tables and having people come in.
I would be representing like Shakespeare, and people would sign up.
I don't remember when that stopped, and I don't remember where it was, but I certainly remember doing it.
In those early years, did you have any normal rules in your syllabus?
Did you have any guidelines that you gave to the students of what you expected?
No.
Some people did.
I mean, I had a syllabus, if you mean assignments and so forth.
Yes, I had a syllabus with the assignments on it and the textbook, and usually it was one page, and that was it.
Did you check roll in those years?
Every day, no, I didn't.
Basically, though, after the first two weeks, at least, I knew who everybody was in the smaller classes.
In the bigger classes, I always left it up to them if they wanted to come to class.
And I think this is one of the reasons that I never had any trouble with students during that time period, because I didn't make them come to class.
If they missed a quiz, they could not make it up.
The assignment dates, though, including the quizzes, were on the sheet.
So anyone who could do satisfactory work without attending the lectures, maybe by reading the textbook and the other materials, that was all right with me.
And you were a pioneer female faculty member.
Did women students turn to you occasionally for any advice or counsel?
No.
Actually, the students who came to me for advice and counsel back then were mostly men, young men.
I think they saw me as mama.
As far as the young women were concerned, I don't know where they went, but they didn't come to me.
And what was the normal title that the students gave you when they spoke to you?
They tended to call me Mrs. McCann.
Of course, I did not have a PhD then, so I would not have been Dr. McCann.
But they tended to call me Mrs. McCann.
And they were polite.
Mrs. McCann, ma'am.
All right, let's back up a little and describe how it was to get settled into this community.
We all found a place to live and children and so forth.
Yes.
Now, Hugh came out a couple of weeks after he was hired.
He came out and stayed with Manuel Davenport for three or four days and bought a house.
And the house cost $19,000.
It was on Carter Creek Parkway.
And it was a nice little brick house.
It had three bedrooms and a very pleasant area.
So we didn't have any trouble with that.
And children were not yet school age?
No, they were not.
And we took them to French's Royal Tot, which actually worked out very well for my daughter.
I think it was not the right place for my son, but I didn't know that then.
It seemed fine.
Do you remember what that daycare cost then?
Yeah, it cost $65 a month for one.
And I think $95, yeah.
And your neighbors, how were they in being receptive to a newcomer?
Well, I didn't like the neighbors, frankly.
I thought them bigots.
For one thing, we had a maid, as everybody did then.
And they were very upset because I let the maid bring her little girl to play with my little girl.
And this caused all kinds of problems.
So I didn't get on very well with the neighbors.
They, I did also, before I worked in the fall, I did go to some of their little cafe clutches and I hated them.
That is not the neighbors, but the, those morning coffees where people would discuss their families and their lives.
And to me, it seemed extremely,
limited and sterile, and this led to my being very anxious to get out of there and talk to Manuel Davenport about the possibility of escape.
But no, the neighbors were not neighbors I would have chosen.
They were not affiliated with the university.
They worked in a factory, and now I can't think where or which.
Was it a shoe factory?
It could have been a shoe factory.
I don't remember, but I do remember that neighbors on both sides worked in a factory and were friends.
And the neighbor behind us, I liked him somewhat better.
He was military.
Across the street from us was Dr. Caperton, the skin person.
They held themselves aloof, the Capertons.
They had a bigger house, and they kind of didn't socialize too much with the rest of us.
In fact, there was a whole little enclave of bigger houses across the street.
But once I got out of the neighborhood, it was pleasant enough.
I mean, it was certainly a nice place to live.
The neighbors were decent people.
They were just very narrow-minded.
What about shopping?
There was nothing much.
There was the Townshire Shopping Center, and that was it.
There was, I believe, a Sears there.
There was a pharmacy with a little diner in it, where they used to have in pharmacies.
And I used to, we only had one car, so actually the,
The semester I spent home alone was not fun because I didn't have the car either and I had the little girl.
But what I would do would be to wheel her to the Townshire Shopping Center.
And there we would have like ice cream sundaes at the little diner inside it and go to Sears maybe.
But there was not much.
There was a Kroger's that was,
Now we're Hastings, you know, Manner East.
And there was the Township Shopping Center.
And there was downtown College Station.
And one thing, I mean downtown Bryan, I'm sorry.
There was nothing downtown College Station except for shoe, couple shoe places and barbershops.
And all the student bars.
One thing I noticed though was that back then when you came into town, all the local merchants gave you these credit cards.
They called you up, and they gave you credit cards that were good for their own stores.
Beverly, Braley.
I understand something terrible happened to him.
He just retired, and then he was killed in an accident that probably wasn't an accident.
Don't put that in the... I forgot about that machine.
Let's see.
Did you become involved in any community activities?
Not right away.
After I started working, I did, because I must say that I had a lot more leisure as an instructor and then later as a lecturer even than I have now.
Now, any spare time is immediately filled in.
Back then, I just taught my classes and went home, so I was a Girl Scout leader.
I worked at the Bryan City Mission.
I worked for the Brazos Valley Literacy Council.
I did all these things.
Church, synagogue, did you attend?
Oh, yeah.
We're Catholic.
We went to church.
Describe the parish you all attended.
Back then we attended, let's see, we attended St.
Mary's, and it was not that different from the way it is now.
I mean, it was full of Aggies.
Yeah, that was it.
St.
Mary's was our parish for years and years.
And then once they built St.
Thomas, we sort of
moved over there, but what frequently happens is that my husband goes to St.
Thomas Aquinas, and I still go to St.
Mary's, because A, I don't like to get up to go to the 830 Mass, and B, I like going to St.
Mary's.
This man, Manuel Davenport, since I won't be able to interview him, tell me as much as you can.
How did you all come to know him in the first place?
Okay.
And then describe him as much as you can, because we need to be sure to include him in this reservoir.
Yeah, he, first of all, invited Hugh to stay with him and look for a house and then helped Hugh find a house.
But how did they even, how did they?
He hired Hugh.
Oh.
There was a search and he hired Hugh.
Oh, in philosophy?
Yeah.
Oh, I'm sorry, I'm sorry.
Yeah, no, no problem.
But there was a search in philosophy and they hired Hugh.
And then they invited him to come out and stay with them.
and find accommodations.
So he did that.
And I was at this time pregnant.
And I told him that I wanted a house.
I said I wanted to start with a house.
So although we didn't have very much money,
With my parents' help, it was possible to buy this house.
And back then, too, it was much easier to get a bank loan.
There wasn't much of a check.
You know, you were an A&M professor, you could have the loan.
So we got this house on Carter Creek Parkway, but the Davenports were very nice to Hugh.
And I can't imagine that happening now that you hire somebody and the head invites this person to stay with them for three or four days and helps them find a house.
So then we came out, and I liked the philosophy department immediately.
It was about how many?
I would say about six.
There was Ed Harris and Davenport and Stadelman and Becca.
Who am I missing?
I don't know, but I remember those four.
I don't think there was anybody else besides Hugh.
Those are the people I remember from parties, that is, as permanent members.
